title: Ramona Parra
text:
Ramona Aurelia Parra Alarcón (May 28, 1926–1946) was a <a href="Chile">Chile</a>an <a href="Nitrate">Nitrate</a> worker and <a href="Communism">communist</a>. She was shot to death during a demonstration in <a href="Santiago%20de%20Chile">Santiago de Chile</a>, also known as the Bulnes Square massacre. She is best known for being the first martyr of the <a href="Communist%20Youth%20of%20Chile">Communist Youth of Chile</a>.
Early life.
Ramona was born on May 28, 1926. She grew up in a small one story house.
Education and communism.
Parra, along with her sisters Flor and Olga, entered the <a href="Communist%20Youth%20of%20Chile">Communist Youth of Chile</a> in 1944 while studying at the Higher Institute of Commerce.
Death.
In 1946, at the age of 19, she was accidentally killed during a march being held by the <a href="Chilean%20Confederation%20of%20Workers">Chilean Confederation of Workers</a>. The workers were protesting for the rights for the miners in <a href="Humberstone%2C%20Chile">Humberstone</a>, <a href="Mapocho%20River">Mapocho</a> and multiple other mining sites, which were denied by <a href="Alfredo%20Duhalde">Alfredo Duhalde</a>.
Legacy.
Brigade.
Her death inspired a communist party named "The <a href="Ramona%20Parra%20Brigade">Ramona Parra Brigade</a>". It was founded in 1969.
